גמ’ השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא
The Gemara is asking on the Mishnah, why do I need to be told he can
a woman himself when I can infer that from the fact he can do it by

tokens.targetSubtopic: גמ’ השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא

tokens.text: גמ’ השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא

tokens.html:
<gray>אמר
רב יוסף מצוה בו יותר מבשלוחו כי הא דרב</gray>

גמ’ השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא.text:
Let’s bring in a few pieces of background info and use it to understand this line of the Gemara.
1) The Aramaic word השתא,

, has a special meaning in Gemara: “Now” [that you’ve told me] X, [how can it be that] Y. So, when we see this type of השתא, we’re expecting it to be followed by 1. a fact we just learned, and 2. something else that is now confusing in light of that fact.
2) We should recognize the words בו, בשלוחו, and מקדש from the Mishnah. When words or phrases from the Mishnah appear in the Gemara, they are often quotations.
3) When the word מיבעיא

is used regarding the Mishnah, it is often used to state or ask why the author of the Mishnah “needed” to include something in the Mishnah.
4) Because the Gemara doesn’t have question marks, a statement without an explanation is often actually a question.
Putting that all together, the Gemara reads: “Now [that the Mishnah told me]
i.e. that he can do it with himself, is needed [to be taught]?”

tokens.enclosingSubtopic: גמ’ השתא בשלוחו מקדש בו מיבעיא

אמר רב יוסף מצוה בו יותר מבשלוחו.text: The Gemara just asked why the Mishnah needs to tell me a man can be mekadesh בו, himself, when I can infer that from he can do it בשלוחו, with his

.
Now, we’re expecting an answer to the question.
The words אמר רב יוסף,

are the standard introduction to a statement of an Amora.
The words מצוה בו יותר מבשלוחו literally translate to “
with himself more than with his

.”
So, we had been expecting a reason the Tana would tell us explicitly he can do it himself when I can infer that from that he can do it with his
with himself more than with his

.”
So it sounds like R Yosef holds that the Tana included the word בו because of a principle called “it’s a bigger mitzvah to do it yourself than with a

.”
We’ll have to understand the exact mechanics of what he’s suggesting.

כי הא דרב ספרא מחריך רישא רבא מלח שיבוטא.text: We just heard R Yosef’s answer to the Gemara’s question, that the Tana included בו to teach a principle called

.
Now the Gemara says כי הא דרב ספרא, “like that of R Safra,” which sounds like we’re introducing a teaching or story from R Safra.
We can tell this is the Gemara speaking and not more from R Yosef because these Amoriam mentioned are after his time.
The two examples mentioned, R Safra singed the head i.e. of an animal, Rava salted something called a

sound like Amoriam being particular to participate in preparing for Shabbos themselves.
This would be an example of R Yosef’s principle, that it is “more” of a
to do something yourself than to do it via another person.

tokens.text:
איכא דאמרי בהא איסורא נמי אית בה
כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה
אמר רב אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה
עד שיראנה שמא יראה בה דבר מגונה
ותתגנה עליו ורחמנא אמר ואהבת לרעך
כמוך
Now let’s see a different version of this same Talmudic discussion that occurred elsewhere
When the Gemara asked why the Mishnah needs the word בו, this version of the Gemara has a different answer, that it was to teach that something to do with the case being discussed has an additional

איכא דאמרי.text:
The words איכא דאמרי literally mean “there is/are” “that [they] say” i.e. “there are those who say.”
This phrase has a technical meaning in Gemara, that some Amora involved the composition of the Gemara had two versions of a given Talmudic discussion, and now we’re going to see the second one.
Sometimes איכא דאמרי introduces a new version of the same discussion between the same people previously mentioned.
Sometimes it introduces a different discussion of the same question that occured in a different place, unknown to the participants in the first discussion and vice versa.
Either way, it differs from a conventional Talmudic debate e.g.

more strongly implies that the people mentioned or their students were arguing directly with one another in the same place, rather than איכא דאמרי which implies two traditions that developed separately.

tokens.html: <gray>כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה</gray>

בהא איסורא נמי אית בה.text:
When we have an איכא דאמרי introducing a new version of the prior Gemara, the Gemara will usually for brevity only mention the part of the new version that diverges from the old one.
However, it isn’t always clear at what point the two diverge. For example, the איכא דאמרי could be replacing the most recent statement, or, it could be a different version of the very first statement, etc.
So, to know how to reconstruct the new version of the Gemara, we will need to try inserting this new line periodically at each point in the existing version, and see at which point it makes sense.
Our Gemara begins by asking
, now that the Mishnah has told me בשלוחו, why does it need to tell me בו? Perhaps this line is an alternative question on our Mishnah. However, the words “in this there is an

” don’t really make sense as a question on the Mishnah.
So, our Gemara first offers the answer of R Yosef, that the בו is to teach you it is more of a
to do something yourself. Perhaps the איכא דאמרי is offering an alternative answer to the Gemara’s question. If so, then whereas R Yosef thinks the בו is to teach that something is a bigger
, this new answer is claiming that it is to teach that something is

. We don’t have full clarity yet what this answer entails, but at least we see that this new line fits as an alternative to R Yosef’s answer.
So, this new version of the Gemara may have began with our same Mishnah, asked the same question
, and offered this answer instead of R Yosef’s.

כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה אמר רב
If the Tana used בו to implicitly teach the requirement of seeing the woman before
, that would be like a halacha which was taught by R Yehuda that he heard from Rav:

tokens.targetSubtopic: כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה אמר רב

tokens.text: אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה עד שיראנה
a woman until he has seen her first.

tokens.targetSubtopic: אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה עד שיראנה

tokens.text: is that if he doesn’t see her, maybe he will later be disgusted by her, and the Torah says “love your fellow as yourself” which being disgusted by your wife would be violating.

tokens.targetSubtopic: שמא יראה בה דבר מגונה ותתגנה עליו ורחמנא אמר ואהבת לרעך כמוך

tokens.html: <gray>איכא דאמרי בהא איסורא נמי אית בה</gray>

tokens.text:
כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה
אמר רב

כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה אמר רב.text:
The words כדרב יהודה אמר רב literally mean “like of Rav Yehuda said Rav.”
The Gemara had just suggested that the extra בו in the Mishnah was to implicitly teach the requirement of seeing a woman before

.
Now, the Gemara is continuing that if so, this teaching would be

this other later teaching we’ve heard explicitly.
The ד which can mean “of” can also mean “[that] of,” and so כד “like of” would really mean “like that of” i.e. “like that teaching of” R Yehuda

Rav.
The phrase רב יהודה אמר רב, R Yehuda amar Rav generally implies that R Yehuda heard the teaching directly from Rav.

tokens.enclosingSubtopic: כדרב יהודה אמר רב דאמר רב יהודה אמר רב

tokens.text:
אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה
עד שיראנה

אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה עד שיראנה.text: The words אסור לאדם שיקדש mean [it is] prohibited to man (or “a man,”) שיקדש, that he will be
את (indicating the one he is being

is:) the woman (presumably “the” woman in the situation i.e. a woman,) עד שיראנה, until that he will see her.
The word אסור i.e. “prohibited” doesn’t clarify for us what kind of
it is, e.g. a Torah prohibition, or a Rabbinic enactment, but we may find clues from context on this point.

tokens.enclosingSubtopic: אסור לאדם שיקדש את האשה עד שיראנה

tokens.text:
שמא יראה בה דבר מגונה
ותתגנה עליו ורחמנא אמר ואהבת לרעך
כמוך

שמא יראה בה דבר מגונה ותתגנה עליו ורחמנא.text:
The word שמא literally means “maybe,” but is often used to introduce Chazal’s reason for instituting a Rabbinic enactment.
So, this possibly reads: [This halacha of R Yehuda amar Rav was established because] שמא, maybe יראה, he will see, בה, in/regarding her, דבר מגונה, a disgusting thing, ותתגנה, and she will become disgusting, עליו, “on” him, i.e. presumably “on his sensibilities.”

tokens.enclosingSubtopic: שמא יראה בה דבר מגונה ותתגנה עליו ורחמנא אמר ואהבת לרעך כמוך

The Gemara suggests that in this version of the discussion, R Yosef was speaking about the second clause of the Mishnah, not the first as in the earlier version.

tokens.targetSubtopic: וכי איתמר דרב יוסף אסיפא איתמר האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה

tokens.text: השתא בשלוחה מיקדשא בה מיבעיא אמר רב יוסף מצוה בה יותר מבשלוחה כי הא דרב ספרא מחריך רישא רבא מלח שיבוטא
The Gemara now proceeds to repeat R Yosef’s answer and the story of the Amoriam preparing for Shabbos, this time said with female conjugations to fit with the second clause of the Mishnah.

tokens.targetSubtopic: השתא בשלוחה מיקדשא בה מיבעיא אמר רב יוסף מצוה בה יותר מבשלוחה כי הא דרב ספרא מחריך רישא רבא מלח שיבוטא

tokens.text:
וכי איתמר דרב יוסף אסיפא איתמר
האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה

וכי איתמר דרב יוסף אסיפא איתמר האשה מתקד.text: The word כי can mean a lot of things but here it seems to mean “when,” and so וכי,

is a passive verb meaning “[it] was said.”
So וכי איתמר,

, “and when [it] was said.”
The phrase דרב יוסף,

means “of R Yosef,” but ד can also mean “[that thing] of,” so here, “[that statement] of R Yosef.”
The phrase אסיפא איתמר means אסיפא,
, it was said. The Mishnah had three clauses, so you might think the
should be the third, but we’ll see that the Gemara means the second, and some Rishonim will use the phrase

, “bottom of the bottom” to refer to the third clause.
In the original version of the Gemara, R Yosef brought the extra בו in the first clause of the Mishnah as his evidence, and now we’re saying in the new version he is bringing the extra בה in the second clause as his evidence.
And then Gemara provides us a quote of this second clause, האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה,

בה via herself or בשלוחה via her shaliach, with now the בה being extra.
So וכי איתמר דרב יוסף אסיפא איתמר,

tokens.text: v’chi itmar d’Rav Yosef a’seifa itmar

וכי איתמר דרב יוסף אסיפא איתמר האשה מתקד.text: , “and when was said that statement of R Yosef, regarding the seifa [i.e. second clause of the Mishnah] it was said,” האשה מתקדשת בה ובשלוחה,
